Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Efficient Coupling of Multilevel Partial Differential Equation Solvers and Advanced Sampling Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
We know today how to simulate many processes on computers, such as air flow around airfoils or how objects deform when a force is applied. However, from a practical perspective, it is often desirable to determine to "quantify the uncertainty" of our predictions, i.e., to be able to say how accurate or inaccurate a computer simulation is when the inputs are not exactly known. An example is how an airfoil behaves when the air ahead is turbulent. In these cases, one needs to simulate many scenarios, an exceedingly expensive proposition. This project aims to develop mathematical tools to make this process more feasible and computationally affordable by taking advantage of multilevel hierarchies in the sampling and solution approach.

Many processes in the sciences and engineering are described by parameter-dependent partial differential equations (PDEs) whose numerical solution is expensive. While their forward solution may be feasible, the computational cost makes it difficult or impossible to statistically evaluate questions such as (i) to quantify the uncertainty in output variables given a known or assumed distribution of parameter values, or (ii) to solve the statistical inverse problem of inferring a probability distribution among parameters from noisy measurements. Both of these questions are typically answered through high-dimensional and consequently very expensive sampling methods. This project will use hierarchical and multilevel decompositions of PDE solvers, coupled with error estimates, to derive vastly faster methods to obtain a sufficient number of samples to achieve statistical sampling with prescribed accuracy. The approach implies that whenever possible, samples and PDE solutions can happen on coarse, cheap levels of their respective hierarchies, and expensive solves are performed only when necessary. The combined use of these hierarchies therefore promises to deliver more, and more informative, samples at a cheaper cost - thereby enabling applications in the sciences and engineering that were not possible before.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed at developing statistical sampling methods for problems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs). PDEs are the universal language of continuum mechanics – i.e., the description of how solids, fluids, and gasses behave and how they react to external forces – but these equations cannot be solved exactly on a piece of paper. Instead, the solutions have to be approximated by finite dimensional representations, and the meshes that are used in this process naturally present a hierarchy of successively more accurate approximations. The foundation for this project is that this hierarchy can be used not only for the solution of partial differential equations, but also in modeling things for which the solution of PDEs is a sub-step.


Specifically, this project was concerned with methods for determining the statistical properties of parameters that appear in PDEs, such as density or mechanical stiffness values. Traditionally, one looked for the “most likely” value by comparing predictions against actual measurements. But, more recently, scientists have been looking for how likely different values may be, and this can only be done by creating large numbers of possible values and predicting how the material would behave if that were the correct value – a process called “sampling”. This project developed methods for both the (i) estimation of errors in the sampling process that result from the inaccurate solution of PDEs, and (ii) the development of sampling strategies that are faster than if one were to just sample using the most accurate solver.

As part of this project, we developed and published a benchmark problem to compare sampling methods for PDEs, providing a foundation for future research of new sampling methods. We also developed the open source C++ SampleFlow library for composing complex statistical sampling algorithms. It is flexible, reusable, and performant and we expect it to be the foundation for future work. We also developed multilevel solver support in deal.II supporting massively-parallel computations on adaptively refined grids based on two different approaches: local smoothing and global coarsening multigrid. By themselves, these new multilevel solvers form the basis for efficient PDE solvers and have seen adoption by various projects. The multilevel solvers can also expose a hierarchy of coarser and coarser discretizations that can be combined with multilevel sampling methods.

There are several broader impacts resulting from this work done for this project: First, the code we developed as part of this project was contributed to open source software libraries and is already in use by other researchers. Secondly, the development of more efficient sampling and multilevel solvers can improve the accuracy and speed of simulations across sciences and industry.
